data.title: A/C Recharge : 1992
data.meta_description: I need to recharge my A/C. I have the can of 134a(in my case) the hose and a gauge. I simply put on the A/C ...
data.text:
I need to recharge my A/C.

I have the can of 134a(in my case) the hose and a gauge.

I simply put on the A/C on Max, hook the hose to the low side, and let it draw refrigerant until the gauge says "charged", or Im out of refrigerant.

Am I right with this???

Just wondering....

Bob

_________________

1995 White Bonneville SE

188340 Miles as of 06/07/10, still running.........

LIM/UIM Work done 4/23/07 at 145000 miles...

You are correct, sir.

Just some tips:

-Don't forget eye protection in case the inevitable happens.

-Be sure to shake the can well before attaching the hose.

-If the system's completely dead, you'll need more than one 12oz. can.

-"Rock" the can between the 12 o'clock and 3 o'clock every few seconds while filling. Also, shake while filling.

-Check pressure often. In-line gauges are perfect for this.

-When the can appears to be drained, hold it up-side down for a minute to get the rest of the freon out.

Does someone here have an A/C pressure chart for the 95?

_________________

-Chris

2006 Grand Prix GT

Sport Red Met. - L32 Supercharged, Tint, Leather, Heated/Power Seats, Remote Start/Keyless, Dual Climate Control, 17" wheels, 70k miles. Mods to come.

1997 Bonneville SE *Sold*

Dark Yellow-Green Met. - Tint (35% front, 5% rear) - CAI - Aftermarket Keyless/Remote Start - Disabled DRLs - Belden Wires, TR55 plugs - Cleared Corners - Silverstars - 190,591 miles when sold

Shaking the can is needed for refrigerant with added stuff like oil, dye, or stop leak. It is not needed for straight refrigerant.

Turning the can upside down will result in charging the refrigerant as a liquid. If the system is fully charged or overcharged, this can result in liquid reaching the compressor, destroying it.

The safe way to charge a can upside down is when there is a vacuum in the system (no refrigerant) and the engine and AC compressor are not running.

I find the quickest way to charge a can into a system is to connect it to the low side with the AC on high, find a warm (not hot) place where the can will sit upright, wire it in place, and go for a ride. The air coming through the condenser and the increased engine speed bring the AC system to equilibrium quickly and allow charging within a few minutes. These conditions cannot be reproduced with the car sitting still unless you have a movie style aircraft engine with a prop in front of your car.

_________________

1998 3.8 Dodge Caravan 214K

2000 3.3 Dodge Caravan 175K

1949 Plymouth Special Deluxe 4-dr sedan 25K (needs some work!)

haro1225 wrote:

I got an A/C recharge kit, but the hose doesn't have a gauge. Should I try to find a gauge?

Also, where is the low side service connector?

If your A/C is low enough on refrigerant for it to have quit, and if you want to be quick & dirty about it, you can add a full can of refrigerant without a guage and be O.K.

bobfather99 wrote:

I need to recharge my A/C.

I have the can of 134a(in my case) the hose and a gauge.

I simply put on the A/C on Max, hook the hose to the low side, and let it draw refrigerant until the gauge says "charged", or Im out of refrigerant.

Am I right with this???

Just wondering....

Bob

Hope that will help a little

Ok, I must be doing something wrong...

I hooked up the can correctly, and Im hearing/seeing the compressor cycling, but its not taking any refrigerant.

Had it hooked up for about 20 minutes(while idling), and its not cold out the vents. I had the selector set to "max", fan on at high speed, engine running.

Anyone want to take a guess as to what Im doing wrong??

Thanks in advance...

_________________

1995 White Bonneville SE

188340 Miles as of 06/07/10, still running.........

LIM/UIM Work done 4/23/07 at 145000 miles...

bobfather99 wrote:

Ok, I must be doing something wrong...

Is the can getting cold (like frost forming on the outside of the can)? If not, no gas is going into the system. Check the valve on the can.

The can of refridgerant has a thin metal seal on the top. Once it is threaded into the valve, you have to close the valve all the way down till the needle punctures the seal, then open the valve to allow the refridgerant flow into the system. You can feel the can get cold, and it will get lighter as the fluid leaves and turns into a gas inside the AC system. When you can't feel the fluid sloshing around when you shake the can, it's empty and time for another one.

I don't care much for the cans with the simple gauge on the hose. Better to use a set of gauges that show you the high and low side pressures so you can see what the system is doing. I also use a vac pump on the system to evacuate it of air before trying to fill it.

Either way, it does take time, but the 20 minutes you've waited should have emptied the can.

_________________

Bye Bye 1990 Bonneville LE... Now it belongs to my daughter

In the Garage: 2009 Subaru Outback, 1987 Camaro, 2006 SV650S, 1995 Regal 182 "ASANAGI", 1962 Ford Galaxie 500, 1995 Ford F150 XL 4WD, 1953 Farmall Cub

I know the seal on the can is pierced, but the can doesnt get cold(I was surprised) and the refrigerant doesnt get into the system. Ill check out the can and hose, and see if something isnt right.

I know the hose makes the good seal on the "low" side port, Im shaking the can from 12-3 o'clock(as posted)

Ill give it another go tomorrow, cause man, its hot!!!

BTW, wheres that filter located on a 95 SE??

Bob

_________________

1995 White Bonneville SE

188340 Miles as of 06/07/10, still running.........

LIM/UIM Work done 4/23/07 at 145000 miles...

bobfather99 wrote:

BTW, wheres that filter located on a 95 SE??

Follow the high pressure line from the condensor on it's way to the evaporator. It follows the frame rail and should be pretty close to the torque-axis motor mount. You'll see a joint in the line with two nuts on it, and a slight bulge in the line that's about 2" long. The Orifice Tube/Filter is inside that bulge. To get it out, discharge the system, seperate the fittings, and grab the end of the plastic with needle-nose pliers. New one goes in the same way.

Ok, but you have a full can of r134a, the valves are open, but the system isn't taking any of the refridgerant in. Either the schreder valve where the low side port is plugged up, or the pressure on the low side of the system is higher than the pressure in the can. This is one of the moments where a set of gauges comes in handy.

_________________

Bye Bye 1990 Bonneville LE... Now it belongs to my daughter

In the Garage: 2009 Subaru Outback, 1987 Camaro, 2006 SV650S, 1995 Regal 182 "ASANAGI", 1962 Ford Galaxie 500, 1995 Ford F150 XL 4WD, 1953 Farmall Cub

Well, I got my system charged, finally!!!

Turns out it was a bad hose. The pin was too long in the hose, which made it so I could pierce the seal, but couldnt pull it back to ley the freon into the system. I took it back and got a new hose, and all was good. Parts store guy gave me a new can of freon for my trouble, too!!!

Only needed one pound of freon to get the system up to perfect.

Thanks to all for your help, it turned out great.

I knew when I saw WillWren and Bill Buttermore(and others) I made the right choice in forums!!!!

_________________

1995 White Bonneville SE

188340 Miles as of 06/07/10, still running.........

LIM/UIM Work done 4/23/07 at 145000 miles...
